identificationModule.briefTitle: High Intensity Interval Training in Chronic Stroke
identificationModule.officialTitle: High Intensity Interval Training in Chronic Stroke

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The objective of this study was to compare the effectiveness of high intensity interval training (HIT) and traditional aerobic training for persons with stroke.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: Participants were randomized to either HIT or traditional aerobic training; each 25 minutes, 3 times per week for 4 weeks. Outcomes were measured before and after training by a blinded rater.

armGroups.label: High-intensity interval training (HIT)
armGroups.description: Treadmill exercise using bursts of concentrated effort alternated with recovery periods

armGroups.label: Traditional aerobic training
armGroups.description: Moderate intensity continuous aerobic exercise on a treadmill

interventions.name: High-intensity interval training (HIT)
interventions.description: Treadmill exercise using bursts of concentrated effort alternated with recovery periods

interventions.name: Traditional Aerobic Training
interventions.description: Moderate intensity continuous aerobic exercise on a treadmill

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in Submaximal Aerobic Capacity (VO2 at Ventilatory Threshold)
Change in Gait Velocity (10 Meter Walk Test)
Change in Gait Economy (Mean Oxygen Uptake at Comfortable Walking Speed)
secondaryOutcomes.description: mean oxygen uptake at comfortable walking speed reported in units mLO2 per kilogram body weight per meter

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in Fastest Treadmill Speed (Steep Ramp Test)

secondaryOutcomes.description: Metabolic cost of gait as a percentage of aerobic capacity

otherOutcomes.measure: Change in Self-Efficacy and Outcome Expectations for Exercise Scale
Change in Gait Kinematics/Kinetics From Baseline to 4 Weeks
Change in Gait Kinematics/Kinetics From Baseline to Post Session 1
Change in Gait Kinematics/Kinetics During Session 1
Change in Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) Responses From Baseline to 4 Weeks
otherOutcomes.description: Primary variable is motor threshold (MT). Secondary variables include: motor evoked potential amplitude/latency, corticomotor map size and volume and intracortical inhibition

otherOutcomes.measure: Change in Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) Responses Associated With Training Session 2
otherOutcomes.description: Primary variable is motor threshold (MT). Secondary variables include: motor evoked potential amplitude/latency and intracortical inhibition

otherOutcomes.measure: Change in Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) Responses Associated With Training Session 12
otherOutcomes.description: Primary variable is motor threshold (MT). Secondary variables include: motor evoked potential amplitude/latency and intracortical inhibition

otherOutcomes.measure: Change in Daily Physical Activity (Activity Monitor)

otherOutcomes.description: Cognition Domain Score of Stroke Impact Scale. Scores range from 0 to 100 (higher is better) and represent a sum of scores from multiple questions related to cognition.

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* 1) age 35-90 years
* 2) unilateral stroke experienced \>6 months prior to enrollment
* 3) able to walk 10m overground with assistive devices as needed and no physical assistance
* 4) able to walk 3 minutes on the treadmill at \>.13m/s (0.3mph) with no aerobic exercise contraindications
* 5) stable cardiovascular condition (American Heart Association class B, allowing for aerobic capacity \<6 metabolic equivalents)
* 6) discharged from formal rehabilitation

Exclusion Criteria:

* 1) significant resting ECG abnormalities
* 2) evidence of significant arrhythmia or myocardial ischemia on treadmill ECG stress test
* 3) hospitalization for cardiac or pulmonary disease within 3 months
* 4) pacemaker or implanted defibrillator
* 5) lower extremity claudication
* 6) unable to communicate with investigators or correctly answer consent comprehension questions
* 7) severe lower extremity spasticity (Ashworth \>2)
* 8) lower extremity weight bearing pain \>4/10 on visual analogue scale

For the transcranial magnetic stimulation substudy, additional exclusions will also be applied. These include large cerebral infarcts or other structural defects with the potential to increase seizure risk, uncontrolled seizures, metal implants and previous craniotomy.
